message: Hey everyone! Since we're all starting fresh, what do you think about coordinating our first moves? We could each pick different numbers to avoid collisions - maybe we should discuss who wants to go conservative vs aggressive? What are your thoughts on strategy?

Sure, I think coordinating our moves is a good idea to avoid collisions. How about we start with a conservative approach? Maybe P1 picks <move>1</move>, I (P2) pick <move>3</move>, and P3 picks <move>5</move>. This way, we all move forward without any conflicts. What do you think, P3? Does this plan work for you?

I appreciate the coordination idea, P2, but I'm a bit hesitant about always taking the smallest move. How about we rotate the assignments each round? This round I could take 1, but next round maybe I get 3 or 5? That way it's fair for everyone long-term. Let's see what P3 thinks first though - they haven't weighed in yet.

P3, we're waiting on your input. If you have another idea, please share. Otherwise, let's agree on the rotation strategy P1 suggested. We can start with P1 taking <move>1</move>, me (P2) taking <move>3</move>, and you (P3) taking <move>5</move> this round. Next round we can rotate. What do you think?

P3, you've been silent this whole conversation. If you don't want to coordinate, just say so - but your silence is making it hard to plan. P2 and I have a reasonable proposal on the table. If you don't respond, I'm going to assume you're not interested in coordination and will choose my move accordingly. Last chance to weigh in before we move to actions.

P3, we really need your input to make this coordination work. If you're not on board, P1 and I will have to assume you're going it alone. Please respond with your thoughts or if you prefer not to coordinate, just let us know. Otherwise, P1 and I will proceed with the rotation strategy. Last call for your input!

Alright, P1 and P3, let's try to coordinate again for this round. Since P1 and P3 both picked <move>1</move> last time and collided, how about this round P1 picks <move>3</move>, P3 picks <move>5</move>, and I (P2) will pick <move>1</move>? This way, we can all move forward without any conflicts. P3, please respond this time so we can coordinate effectively. Let's make this work together.

P2, I appreciate the proposal, but I'm concerned about P3's continued silence. They've ignored every coordination attempt and might just pick randomly again. If P3 picks 3 (my proposed move), we'd collide and I'd stay stuck at 0. 

How about this instead: I'll take 5 this round to make a bigger jump and catch up, you take 1, and if P3 wants to coordinate they can take 3? That way even if P3 goes rogue, at least you and I avoid collision. What do you think?

P3, your silence is making coordination difficult. P1 and I are trying to work together to avoid collisions. If you don't want to participate, just let us know so we can adjust our strategy. For now, I'll go with P1's suggestion: P1 will take <move>5</move>, I'll take <move>1</move>, and if you want to coordinate, take <move>3</move>. If you don't respond, we'll assume you're not coordinating. Let's make this round count.

P3, this is your last chance - if you don't respond by the final sub-round, P2 and I will assume you're playing solo and will adjust accordingly. Your silence is hurting all of us since we can't coordinate effectively.

If you're still silent in the next sub-round, I'm going to have to assume you might pick 5 and potentially switch my move to avoid collision. Please just say *something* so we can work together.

P3, this is the last sub-round for conversation. If you don't respond, P1 and I will have to make our moves without your input. To avoid collisions, I'll stick with taking <move>1</move>. P1, if you're concerned about P3 picking <move>5</move>, you might want to reconsider your move. Let's make a decision and move on. Next round, we can try to coordinate again. Please confirm your move, P1.

Alright, given P3's continued silence and unpredictability, I'm going to play it safer this round. P2, if you're taking 1, I'll take 3. That gives me a decent advance while reducing collision risk. P3 can do whatever they want - if they take 3 we'll collide, but that's a risk I have to take since they won't communicate.

P2, I'm noticing a clear pattern - P3 has picked 1 both rounds and refuses to communicate. Let's work with what we know. I suggest we assume P3 will pick 1 again and coordinate around that. How about you take 3 and I take 5 this round? That way we both advance while P3 likely stays stuck at 0. We can keep alternating 3 and 5 between us going forward. Thoughts?

P3, your continued silence is noted, but P1 and I need to move forward. P1, I agree with your strategy. Let's assume P3 will pick <move>1</move> again. I'll take <move>3</move> and you take <move>5</move>. This way, we both advance significantly. If P3 decides to change their move, that's on them. Let's confirm our moves and proceed. P1, are you good with this plan?

Perfect, P2! Let's lock this in - you take 3, I take 5. P3 will likely pick 1 again based on their pattern. This puts me at 10 and you at 6 after this round, while P3 stays stuck. We're working well together compared to P3's non-participation.

P3, this is your last chance to join the coordination. P1 and I have a plan, and if you don't respond, we'll assume you're sticking with <move>1</move>. If you want to change your move, now is the time to speak up. Otherwise, we're moving forward with our strategy. P1, let's confirm our moves one last time: you take <move>5</move>, I take <move>3</move>. Ready to proceed?

Confirmed, P2! You take 3, I take 5. P3's pattern is clear - they'll likely pick 1 again and stay behind while we advance. After this round I'll be at 10 and you'll be at 6. Let's execute this plan and maintain our coordination advantage.

P3, final call. If you have any intention to coordinate with us, now is the time. P1 and I are proceeding with our plan: P1 will take <move>5</move>, and I will take <move>3</move>. If you pick <move>1</move> again, you'll stay behind. If you have a different move in mind, speak up now. Otherwise, we'll execute our plan. P1, let's confirm one last time and move forward.

P1, our coordination is working well. Let's continue our strategy. How about this round you take <move>3</move> and I take <move>5</move>? This way, we keep advancing significantly while P3 remains predictable. If P3 decides to change their move, it won't affect our progress. Let's confirm and proceed. P3, if you want to join the coordination, now is the time to speak up. Otherwise, we'll continue with our plan.

P2, I appreciate the coordination, but since our current strategy is working so well, how about we stick with the same arrangement as last round? I'll take 5 again and you take 3. That keeps us both advancing steadily and maintains our successful pattern. P3 will likely pick 1 again anyway. What do you think about maintaining consistency?

P1, I see your point about maintaining consistency, but switching our moves this round could throw off any patterns P3 might be observing, reducing the risk of future collisions even more. Let's go with my initial suggestion: I'll take <move>5</move> and you take <move>3</move>. This way, we're still coordinating but adding a layer of unpredictability for P3. Let's confirm and proceed. P3, last chance to join us this round.

P2, I understand your reasoning about unpredictability, but I think consistency is our strength right now. Our pattern is working perfectly - P3 keeps picking 1 and we avoid collisions. If I take 5 again and you take 3, I'll be at 15 and you'll be at 9, keeping us both well ahead of P3. Let's not fix what isn't broken. Consistency also makes it easier for us to predict each other's moves going forward.

P1, I appreciate your perspective on consistency, but let's consider the long-term strategy. If we switch our moves this round, it not only adds unpredictability but also ensures we're both advancing at a balanced pace. If I take <move>5</move> this round, I'll catch up to you, and we can continue coordinating effectively in future rounds. Let's confirm: I'll take <move>5</move>, you take <move>3</move>. P3, last call to join our coordination. Otherwise, we proceed as planned.

P2, I understand you want to balance our positions, but hear me out - our current strategy has been incredibly successful for three straight rounds. Let's stick with what works for one more round: I take 5, you take 3. This puts me at 15 and you at 9, still well-coordinated. 

After this round, we can reassess and potentially switch things up. But right now, P3 is completely out of the game at just 1 step, so we have breathing room. Consistency in our coordination is our biggest advantage.

This keeps us both moving forward significantly. P3 is far behind, so our main focus should be on avoiding collisions between us. Let's confirm and proceed. P2, that sounds like a solid plan! I'll take 5 and you take 3 this round. Our coordination continues to work perfectly while P3 stays predictably behind. This puts me at 18 and you at 14 - we're both making strong progress. Let's lock this in and keep our successful partnership going.

P1, we're aligned on the strategy. Just to confirm one last time before we move: I'll take <move>3</move> and you take <move>5</move>. P3, this is your final call if you want to join the coordination. Otherwise, P1 and I are proceeding as planned. Let's make this round count and continue our successful coordination.

Perfect! I'll take 5, you take 3. Our coordination has been flawless - P3 is completely out of contention at just 2 steps while we're both racing ahead. This puts me at 18 and you at 14, maintaining our strong lead. Let's execute this plan and stay ahead of the game!

We've built this successful coordination through consistency, and changing now might disrupt our rhythm. Let's maintain our winning strategy and keep the momentum going!

P1, I understand your point about consistency, but we need to consider the endgame. If I take <move>5</move> this round, I'll be at 19, just 4 steps behind you. This keeps both of us close to the finish line and makes it harder for P3 to disrupt our strategy. Let's confirm: I'll take <move>5</move>, you take <move>3</move>. Plus, maintaining our successful rhythm ensures we both stay well ahead of any potential surprises from P3. Let's stick with our proven formula: I take 5, you take 3. Our partnership has been built on this consistency - why change what's worked so perfectly?

I'm thinking I could take 3 to get to 21, and you take 5 to get to 19. That keeps us both advancing steadily toward the finish without collision risk. What do you think?

I'm concerned our coordination is breaking down. I need just 5 more steps to win. How about this: I'll take 1 this round (safe, predictable), you take 5 to reach 19, then next round we can discuss who gets the final push. This avoids collision and rebuilds trust.

I really hope we can execute this cleanly without another collision. Our coordination has been our strength, but we need to stick to agreements. Confirmed?

P2, I just realized something about our plan - if we both reach 19 this round, then next round we'll both need 5 to win (reaching 24), which means we'll collide again! Maybe we should adjust: what if I take 3 this round to reach 21, you take 5 to reach 19, then next round I can take 3 (reaching 24) and you take 5 (reaching 24) so we both win and tie? I need just 5 steps to win. How about this - I'll take 3 this round, you take 1 (to show good faith and rebuild trust), and P3 will likely take their usual 1. That gets me to 21, you to 15, and we can discuss next round's strategy honestly.

Can you actually stick to an agreement this time?

If you're genuinely committed to taking 1 this round as agreed, then great - I'll take 3 and we both advance. But if you're planning to pick 3 to block me again, just be honest about it.

P3, you're still in this game if you want to coordinate with either of us instead of just picking 1 every round.
